channel.title: Comments on: Approach the SQL Community without hesitation!
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Pinal Dave
item.dc:creator: Pinal Dave
item.content:encoded:
Very nice post.

As Denis said it is really not possible to know all, however, it is not difficult to go to community and ask for more.

I have realized many times, when I put something out, people help me, suggest me and guide me to become better. I wonder, people would have never helped me if I have not put myself out in community and shared my knowledge.

I think excellent post and everyone should read it.

item.title: By: Tim Mitchell
item.dc:creator: Tim Mitchell
item.description: Ted, excellent post and a spot-on observation. I'm continually impressed with the way SQL Server folks make themselves available freely to help others.
item.content:encoded: Ted, excellent post and a spot-on observation. I’m continually impressed with the way SQL Server folks make themselves available freely to help others.

item.title: By: Cameron Mergel
item.dc:creator: Cameron Mergel
item.content:encoded:
Excellent post. Couldn’t agree with you more. Great community and very approachable.

Cameron

item.title: By: Jes B
item.dc:creator: Jes B
item.description: This is an excellent post! Every word is true! I can't express how grateful I am to have the Twitter SQL community, the #sqlhelp hash tag, my user group, SQLServerCentral.com, LessThanDot.com, and the list goes on and on. I've had a thousand questions and I've never once felt "stupid" for asking them.
item.content:encoded: This is an excellent post! Every word is true! I can’t express how grateful I am to have the Twitter SQL community, the #sqlhelp hash tag, my user group, SQLServerCentral.com, LessThanDot.com, and the list goes on and on. I’ve had a thousand questions and I’ve never once felt “stupid” for asking them.

item.title: By: wnylibrarian
item.dc:creator: wnylibrarian
item.description: A very nice post. One of the saddest tragedies is people too scared to ask for help. Iâ€™ve always ascribed to the notion that at one time *everyone* was a beginner, and no matter how proficient everyone needs a helping hand on occasion. Being a librarian in the Library Automation field Iâ€™m constantly pulled in two different directions â€“ traditional responsibilities of being a â€˜librarianâ€™ and the database/SQL community. When needed Iâ€™ve asked questions of the SQL community and Iâ€™m so grateful for those that have helped, and continue to help me. They are wonderfully approachable with a fantastic enthusiasm to help! I always walk up and talk, and I thank everyone for being there!
item.content:encoded: A very nice post. One of the saddest tragedies is people too scared to ask for help. Iâ€™ve always ascribed to the notion that at one time *everyone* was a beginner, and no matter how proficient everyone needs a helping hand on occasion. Being a librarian in the Library Automation field Iâ€™m constantly pulled in two different directions â€“ traditional responsibilities of being a â€˜librarianâ€™ and the database/SQL community. When needed Iâ€™ve asked questions of the SQL community and Iâ€™m so grateful for those that have helped, and continue to help me. They are wonderfully approachable with a fantastic enthusiasm to help! I always walk up and talk, and I thank everyone for being there!

item.title: By: Janice Lee
item.dc:creator: Janice Lee
item.content:encoded:
Where was this three months ago when I needed it? ðŸ˜‰ But seriously though, I have better luck of getting a reply when I DM @MidnightDBA than when I call my cable company.

Thanks, good post.

-J

item.title: By: Jorge Segarra
item.dc:creator: Jorge Segarra
item.description: Great post Ted! Great advice on approaching folks. The experts in the community want to talk to you just as much as you want to talk to them. And like you mentioned, just the #sqlhelp tag on Twitter alone shows how much the community is eager and willing to help anyone out (unless they spam it with plagiarized content...).
item.content:encoded: Great post Ted! Great advice on approaching folks. The experts in the community want to talk to you just as much as you want to talk to them. And like you mentioned, just the #sqlhelp tag on Twitter alone shows how much the community is eager and willing to help anyone out (unless they spam it with plagiarized content…).

item.title: By: Christiaan Baes (chrissie1)
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Baes (chrissie1)
item.description: But why do you never come when I call you?
item.content:encoded: But why do you never come when I call you?

item.title: By: traingamer
item.dc:creator: traingamer
item.description: Well said. I tend to search for my own answers first, but there's no point in being shy when you can't find a suitable answer.
item.content:encoded: Well said. I tend to search for my own answers first, but there’s no point in being shy when you can’t find a suitable answer.

item.title: By: Mark Vaillancourt
item.dc:creator: Mark Vaillancourt
item.description: TRU DAT! I joined this community last Fall and I have been really awed by how willing people are to help out.
item.content:encoded: TRU DAT! I joined this community last Fall and I have been really awed by how willing people are to help out.
